item.title: 09_Introduction
item.description: Source: TW ŚRĀDDHA This subject is of great practical importance from several points of view. Definition of śrāddha The Brahmapurāṇa defines śrāddha as follows: ‘whatever is given with faith to brāhmaṇas intending it to be for the (benefit of) pitṛs at a proper time, in a proper place, to deserving persons and in accordance with the prescribed procedure is called śrāddha1’. item.title: 10 Ekoddiṣṭa and Other Śrāddhas
item.description: CHAPTER X EKODDIṢṬA AND OTHER ŚRĀDDHAS Having dealt at great length with Pārvaṇaśrāddha which is the model of all śrāddhas it is now time to speak of Ekoddiṣṭa śrāddha that is a modification of Pārvaṇaśrāddha1. The word Ekoddiṣṭa means ’that in which only one deceased person2 is intended (to be invoked or benefited)’. The Pārvaṇaśrāddha is intended for three paternal ancestors and is thus distinguished from Ekoddiṣṭa. In śān. gr. IV.
